segment.source: Domain member Disable machine account password changes (Windows 10)
segment.target: Domain member Disable machine account password changes (Windows 10)

segment.source: Describes the best practices, location, values, and security considerations for the Domain member Disable machine account password changes security policy setting.
segment.target: Describes the best practices, location, values, and security considerations for the Domain member Disable machine account password changes security policy setting.

segment.source: Domain member: Disable machine account password changes
segment.target: Domain member: Disable machine account password changes

segment.source: Describes the best practices, location, values, and security considerations for the Domain member: Disable machine account password changes security policy setting.
segment.target: Describes the best practices, location, values, and security considerations for the Domain member: Disable machine account password changes security policy setting.

segment.source: The Domain member: Disable machine account password changes policy setting determines whether a domain member periodically changes its machine account password.
segment.target: The Domain member: Disable machine account password changes policy setting determines whether a domain member periodically changes its machine account password.

segment.source: Setting its value to Enabled prevents the domain member from changing the machine account password.
segment.target: Setting its value to Enabled prevents the domain member from changing the machine account password.

segment.source: Setting it to Disabled allows the domain member to change the machine account password as specified by the value of the Domain member: Maximum machine account password age policy setting, which is every 30 days by default.
segment.target: Setting it to Disabled allows the domain member to change the machine account password as specified by the value of the Domain member: Maximum machine account password age policy setting, which is every 30 days by default.

segment.source: By default, devices that belong to a domain are automatically required to change the passwords for their accounts every 30 days.
segment.target: By default, devices that belong to a domain are automatically required to change the passwords for their accounts every 30 days.

segment.source: Devices that are no longer able to automatically change their machine password are at risk of a malicious user determining the password for the system's domain account.
segment.target: Devices that are no longer able to automatically change their machine password are at risk of a malicious user determining the password for the system's domain account.

segment.source: Verify that the Domain member: Disable machine account password changes option is set to Disabled.
segment.target: Verify that the Domain member: Disable machine account password changes option is set to Disabled.

segment.source: Do not enable this policy setting.
segment.target: Do not enable this policy setting.

segment.source: Machine account passwords are used to establish secure channel communications between members and domain controllers and between the domain controllers within the domain.
segment.target: Machine account passwords are used to establish secure channel communications between members and domain controllers and between the domain controllers within the domain.

segment.source: After it is established, the secure channel transmits sensitive information that is necessary for making authentication and authorization decisions.
segment.target: After it is established, the secure channel transmits sensitive information that is necessary for making authentication and authorization decisions.

segment.source: Do not use this policy setting in an attempt to support dual-boot scenarios that use the same machine account.
segment.target: Do not use this policy setting in an attempt to support dual-boot scenarios that use the same machine account.

segment.source: If you want to dual-boot installations that are joined to the same domain, give the two installations different computer names.
segment.target: If you want to dual-boot installations that are joined to the same domain, give the two installations different computer names.

segment.source: This policy setting was added to the Windows operating system to make it easier for organizations that stockpile pre-built computers that are put into production months later; those devices do not have to be rejoined to the domain.
segment.target: This policy setting was added to the Windows operating system to make it easier for organizations that stockpile pre-built computers that are put into production months later; those devices do not have to be rejoined to the domain.

segment.source: Computer ConfigurationWindows SettingsSecurity SettingsLocal PoliciesSecurity Options
segment.target: Computer ConfigurationWindows SettingsSecurity SettingsLocal PoliciesSecurity Options

segment.source: The following table lists the actual and effective default values for this policy.
segment.target: The following table lists the actual and effective default values for this policy.

segment.source: Default values are also listed on the policy’s property page.
segment.target: Default values are also listed on the policy’s property page.

segment.source: This section describes features and tools that are available to help you manage this policy.
segment.target: This section describes features and tools that are available to help you manage this policy.

segment.source: Changes to this policy become effective without a device restart when they are saved locally or distributed through Group Policy.
segment.target: Changes to this policy become effective without a device restart when they are saved locally or distributed through Group Policy.

segment.source: This section describes how an attacker might exploit a feature or its configuration, how to implement the countermeasure, and the possible negative consequences of countermeasure implementation.
segment.target: This section describes how an attacker might exploit a feature or its configuration, how to implement the countermeasure, and the possible negative consequences of countermeasure implementation.

segment.source: By default, devices running Windows Server that belong to a domain automatically change their passwords for their accounts every certain number of days, typically 30.
segment.target: By default, devices running Windows Server that belong to a domain automatically change their passwords for their accounts every certain number of days, typically 30.

segment.source: If you disable this policy setting, devices that run Windows Server retain the same passwords as their machine accounts.
segment.target: If you disable this policy setting, devices that run Windows Server retain the same passwords as their machine accounts.

segment.source: Devices that cannot automatically change their account password are at risk from an attacker who could determine the password for the machine's domain account.
segment.target: Devices that cannot automatically change their account password are at risk from an attacker who could determine the password for the machine's domain account.

segment.source: Verify that the Domain member: Disable machine account password changes setting is configured to Disabled.
segment.target: Verify that the Domain member: Disable machine account password changes setting is configured to Disabled.
